item.title: Aggregate design
item.description: Most business domains have very interconnected Entities, sometimes up to the point where there is always a path going from any Entity to any other. We can try to minimize the number of associations in our design, and this is a good practice but it can lead to a translation loss between business and software. In a typical object model, it is difficult to clearly see the boundaries of a change. This is particularly acute in systems with concurrent access such as Web applications.

item.title: Anemic Domain Model
item.description: An Anemic Domain Model is something that can be found a lot of projects and, astonishingly, is often viewed as a good practice. But as you may already have deduced from its name, it doesn’t sound like something desirable and certainly not in DDD-oriented software.

item.title: Behavior and services
item.description: Sometimes behavior doesn’t fit into Entities or Value Objects. Pure operations may exist in the domain and should therefore be modeled as such. Domain-Driven-Design propose the Service pattern to model these operations.

item.title: Entities and Value Objects
item.description: Modeling business concepts with objects may seem very intuitive at first sight but there are a lot of difficulties awaiting us in the details. To clarify the meaning of model elements and propose a set of design practices, Domain-Driven Design defines three patterns that express the model: Entities, Value Objects and Services. This chapter will focus on Entities and Value Objects, leaving Services for their own chapter.

item.title: Using development snapshots
item.description: Sometimes there is a need to use a development version of a SeedStack component in your project, for testing purposes. This guide will help you configure Maven to access SeedStack SNAPSHOT dependencies.

item.title: HTTPS with Undertow
item.description: This guide will help you generate a certificate and configure Undertow to use it for HTTPS.

item.title: Generating a SeedStack project
item.description: Starting a project from scratch with Maven is not difficult but SeedStack makes it simpler with its generator. This guide goes through the generation process, step-by-step.

item.title: JPA, step-by-step
item.description: This guide details step-by-step how to configure JPA in SeedStack, to access an existing relational database.

item.title: SeedStack on WebSphere
item.description: IBM WebSphere Application Server (WAS) is a complex Web application server that can pose some challenges to developers. The goal of this guide is to aggregate useful information about deploying SeedStack application on WAS successfully.

item.title: JAX-RS basics
item.description: JAX-RS is a specification providing a standard way to write REST resources in Java. SeedStack implements the JAX-RS standard through the Jersey 2 implementation.

item.title: RESTful API design
item.description: The Representational State Transfer (REST) architectural style was defined in 2000 by Roy Fielding. This architectural style defines a set of constraints based on the Web architecture.

item.title: Conversion to WAR
item.description: SeedStack projects created by the generate goal of the SeedStack Maven plugin are designed to be run from command-line with an embedded Web server. You can convert this kind of project to a classic WAR.

item.title: Creating an add-on
item.description: SeedStack is an extensible solution that can be enriched with add-ons to provide new functionality or features. Writing an add-on is not a difficult task as it is very similar to writing an application but some rules and conventions must be obeyed. This guide will describe these rules and conventions.
